ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was also recorded, which I found very nice to have to review after the class had taken place, or if I missed a class and needed to catch up.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the fundamentals of organometallics. Very similar to intro to inorganic chemistry.
Knowledge of transition metal complexes, specifically with regards to organic ligands.
Gave insight into organometallic reactivity at a level not much more advanced than CHEM 252. By the end, I felt more confident in my ability to draw mechanisms for organometallic transformations.

I gained knowledge of basic organometallic properties and reactions. I felt it greatly expanded upon 252 and helped go more in depth.  This class gave me more detailed knowledge of certain things I hadn't learned in 252 before. Great class overall.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strength is interesting material. Weakness is very long lectures and presentation of material that is somewhat like a list and not a complete explanation of topics. It would be better if lectures included more examples of the material learned.

Lecture style is smooth, slides are well paced and well written.

Feedback on problem sets could be a lot more clear.

Professor Crabtree's dedication to sharing interesting and novel research results alongside his curriculum was an incredible asset. He also shared many wonderful examples in chemical history in which "well-understood" mechanism were reevaluated.

Strengths: very good lectures, awesome material, and a great and engaging professor. Also, the psets were challenging but not so much so, and the professor was always very open to helping out students through office hours.
Weaknesses: None really.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Offer of recorded lectures was good. Problem sets were due at a reasonable time.

The final exam was required to be taken in a specific 3 hour slot. This could have been improved greatly, as some people may not be in the same timezones as New Haven.
I'm not sure. Professor Crabtree did a great job with the lectures and uploading the slides. It's basically as good as it can get.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes I would recommend this course to another student. The lecture material is interesting and the work is not overwhelming. The only negative is the final exam was unnecessarily difficult and covered material not taught in the course.
If you're in the chem major, yes. Otherwise, why are you taking this course? It's hyper specific, and only half a credit.

YES!!!!! If you like inorganic chemistry or are even a bit interested I think you will love this course, no matter who is teaching it because they are all great instructors. You will learn so much. You get much more deep examples than 252 and some current topics which are great. Please take this course even if you aren't sure. It is wonderful.
